In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  India's  infrastructure  investment  requirements  are  estimated  at  around  $514  billion 
during the Eleventh Five Year Plan, 2007–20111 to sustain gross domestic product growth at 
9%.  However,  fiscal  constraints  to  meeting  investment  requirements  require  a  significant 
portion, or around $150 billion, to come from the private sector.2 In addition to mitigating fiscal 
constraints, the Government of India (the Government) is keen to leverage the private sector’s 
service delivery and project management efficiency. The Government has thus embarked on 
broad reforms to enable greater private sector participation in infrastructure, emphasizing the 
public–private partnership (PPP) modality.  
2.  The Government's approach is being supported by several Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) technical assistance (TA) initiatives designed to mainstream PPP in India.3 The TAs are 
focusing on capacity building for institutionalizing PPPs across the country, developing PPP 
project  pipelines,  and  for  assisting  states  and  sectors  in  developing  a  supportive  policy 
environment. These initiatives have resulted in 23 PPP cells in central and state levels and 
significant  mainstreaming  of  infrastructure  development  through  PPP  across  sectors. 
Consequently, over 200 potential PPP infrastructure projects are now entering the market. 
Further assistance for transaction advisory has also been provided in the health and education 
sectors where the PPP modality has not yet percolated as has support for catalyzing long-term 
funding for PPPs.4 In light of the success of these initial efforts, the 'next generation' of PPP-
enabling policies and institutions is required at the national level to streamline and further evolve 
the PPP policy and enabling environment to ensure consistency across states and to provide 
additional mechanisms to generate high-quality transactions in the existing and evolving policy 
environment. In this context, the TA supports new centralized advisory institutions, procurement 
processes,  and  a  PPP  policy  framework  based  on  a  set  of  principles,  as  opposed  to  a 
prescriptive approach. The focus of the TA is to evolve the policy and regulatory environment 
and develop guidance mechanisms to generate high-quality transactions given that the project 
pipeline has expanded across sectors.5 The pipeline now extends to sectors where PPP is 
uncommon and involves state government sponsors, where there is a need to further improve 
the policy, regulatory, and legal framework. 
3.  The objectives for the next generation of PPP reforms is to build upon existing initiatives 
to establish policies, processes, and entities which can assist project sponsors in (i) undertaking 
PPP projects through streamlined processes and principles; (ii) attaining appropriate public 
control  and  monitoring  of  PPP  projects;  (iii)  developing  governance  structures  to  facilitate 
competitiveness, equitability, and transparency in PPP procurement; and (iv) ensure that a 
value-for-money (VFM) rationale is adopted with optimal risk allocation in project structuring.

4.  Fact-finding and consultation missions in December 2008 and February, March, and 
August 2009 finalized the TA scope. The TA is in line with ADB's country operations business 
plan, country partnership strategy, and Strategy 2020, which envisage greater ADB involvement 
in private sector development. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Given the public nature of services provided by a PPP infrastructure facility, the public 
sector sponsor requires a legal-regulatory and policy framework to enter into contracts based on 
(i) transparent and objective processes for project and concessionaire selection, with VFM being 
a factor; (ii) clearly defined approval, compliance, and oversight jurisdiction over PPP projects, 
especially with regard to the rights of municipal and local government authorities; and (iii) clear 
definitions  of  the  roles,  responsibilities,  and  rights  of  parties  in  the  governing  instruments 
(concession  agreement,  regulations,  etc.).  The  PPP  legal-regulatory  and  policy  framework 
empowers the private sector to collect and retain revenues and seek revision of user charges. 
6.  Promoting good governance of the project utility and procuring efficient and affordable 
services are at the heart of PPP. The foundation for accountability and efficiency, crucial to 
protecting the interests of shareholders and investors, should be provided in the legal-regulatory 
and policy framework. With regard to regulation, a balance must be struck between competing 
issues such as prices, customer service, environment protection, ability to pay, and need to use. 
Provisions  for  extraordinary  price  adjustments  must  be  provided  for  on  specific  and 
predetermined grounds such as a change in service obligations, change in law, breach of 
contract, scope of Government interventions, and terms such as payment of a subsidy, etc.   
 
7.  PPP  transactions  under  this  framework  would  involve  private  participants  making 
investment arrangements with the grantor of the concession or joint venture partner. Additional 
arrangements may include contracts on the sale and/or supply of goods and services including 
engineering,  procurement,  construction,  operation  and  maintenance,  modernization,  and 
financing. 
 
8.  A PPP manual based on the legal-regulatory and policy framework will provide public 
and private partners with procedural guidance covering each stage of the PPP development and 
implementation process. The PPP policy manual should reflect best practices while articulating 
an informative rather than prescriptive approach. It should provide guidance on using PPP in a 
range of projects across subsectors. The operational and procedural guidance provided in the 
PPP policy framework dovetails the regulatory and legal framework described above. Viewed in 
this context, the PPP policy manual provides detailed guidance on project identification and 
optional appraisal including VFM analysis, statutory processes and their implications for the 
structure  of  the  procurement  process  and  the  pattern  of  risk  allocation,  procurement  and 
contract award, construction, operation, and post-project review.  
 
9.  This discussion of the legal-regulatory and policy framework underlines the need for the 
public sector sponsor to (i) fully scope projects, (ii) effectively manage the bidding process, (iii) 
identify potential risks, and (iv) allocate risks to the project participant best placed to manage 
them. The focus of the public sector sponsor is on contract development to obtain bids and 
identify and allocate risk. The public sector sponsor will need to design a suitable procurement 
timetable,  process,  and  documentation  framework,  especially  for  requesting  proposal 
documents. Ideally, the request for proposals should set out details of the project, requirements, 
and deliverables, including legal, financial, design, and technical criteria. In a successful PPP 
project, the government sponsor is required to appropriately allocate risk in project documents

3
with an awareness of bidder, financier, and equity issues, as private firms will resist taking on 
risks that they cannot manage. This requires finalization of project documents, including (i) the 
project deeds, which grant the right to the private firm to develop the project and govern the risk 
allocation between the government and the project vehicle; (ii) engineering and procurement 
contracts, which govern the relationship between the project company and the contractor; (iii) 
operation and maintenance contracts, which govern the relationship between the project vehicle 
and the operator and set out the non-core services of the asset and its maintenance for its 
useful life; and (iv) tripartite agreement(s) among the project vehicle, financiers, government 
sponsor, and other parties. Tripartite agreements allow the public sector sponsor to monitor 
issues under subcontracts.  
 
10.  Closely aligned with developing a PPP manual and optimizing contracts to suit specific 
transactions is creating an independent national knowledge-management body to manage and 
support the improvement of the legal-regulatory and policy environment. The body will be 
responsible for managing the development of the PPP manual and PPP policy framework and 
assist in drafting contracts that address transaction-specific issues. 
     
  III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA impact will be enhanced private sector investment in infrastructure during the 
current and succeeding 5-year plans, improving infrastructure across the country with private 
investment inflows and efficient resource management. 
 
12.  TA outcomes will be an improved PPP-enabling environment with streamlined PPP 
processes and guidelines, as well as sector, legal, and regulatory frameworks for catalyzing 
PPP investments. The development of a central PPP entity will enhance the PPP process and 
awareness of it in local, state, and central governments, with streamlined PPP coordination 
between government entities. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The  TA  will  have  four  core  activities  and  support  supplementary  activities  for  PPP 
mainstreaming to assist in achieving the next generation of PPP development. Core activities 
are developing (i) a national PPP policy framework; (ii) a comprehensive PPP manual to include 
project development, procurement, and technical guidance; (iii) a national PPP body to provide 
guidance, oversight, and monitoring; and (iv) sector-specific regulatory inputs. 
 
14.  A national principle-based PPP policy framework will be designed under the TA, rather 
than a prescriptive approach, to foster innovation and flexibility while providing guidance. The 
framework  will  be  designed  to  include  (i)  PPP  principles  and  guidelines  and  (ii)  enabling 
instruments for PPP policy and knowledge dissemination. International, national, and state best 
practices will be analyzed to develop principles and guidelines for PPP, addressing such issues 
as  PPP  definitions,  processes,  possible  institutions,  project  structures,  and  recommended 
legislative arrangements. This will require a comprehensive review of PPP legislation,6 including 
                                                 
6  Laws governing various sectors include the Electricity Act, 2003; Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act,1997; 
and  National  Highway  Authority  of  India  Act,  1998.  Superimposed  on  these  acts  are  binding  rulings  and 
instruments  issued  by  statute  to  regulate  specific  sectors,  activities,  and  businesses.  These  may  include 
regulations, practice directions, licenses, quality of supply standards, tariff orders, performance standards, safety 
standards, environmental issues, and case-specific orders.

4     
central  and  state  legislation,  regulatory  frameworks  and  rulings,  and  court  orders, 
recommending legislative changes as appropriate. PPP principles will be developed for each 
sector based on analyses of sector policies and challenges to attracting private investments. 
India-specific tools for undertaking VFM and risk analysis will be developed, following a review 
of global practices. Enabling instruments for PPP policy and knowledge dissemination will likely 
include a PPP index, a showcase of PPP projects, an infrastructure index tracker for PPP, and 
an annuity-funding scheme modeled on a private finance initiative in the United Kingdom.  
 
15.  The development of a national level PPP manual will require a comprehensive review of 
existing  national  and  international  manuals;  PPP-procurement  processes  and  guidelines; 
sector-specific guidance material such as standardized concession agreements and regulatory 
and legal regimes; and PPP-enabling instruments such as the Viability Gap Funding scheme of 
the Government. As the PPP manual will suggest the role of individual stakeholders according 
to best practice at each stage of project development and implementation, developing the policy 
manual will require consultation with all stakeholders, including project sponsors, regulators, 
government agencies, developers, and consumers.  
 
16.  The TA will support the development and institutionalization of the proposed national 
PPP entity, "3 P India," to act as the single reference point for PPP development under the next 
generation  of  PPP  mainstreaming  reforms.  Taking  forward  the  concept  developed  by  the 
Department of Economic Affairs (DEA), the TA will assist in defining the entity's aims, business 
plans, and operating functions, which may include (i) knowledge management (to oversee 
development of the PPP manual, PPP policy framework, sector-specific regulatory guidance, 
and to house panels of transaction, technical, financial, and legal advisors); (ii) compliance 
(oversight  of  PPP  processes,  approvals  for  project  structuring,  and  advisory  funding);  (iii) 
regulation (intermediation during project implementation); (iv) project preparation assistance 
(development funds); and/or (v) oversight (a national PPP audit unit for evaluating PPP projects). 
The TA will review and refine the entity's proposed institutional and legal structure, including its 
shareholding  structure  (100%  government  owned  or  partly  privately  owned),  articles  and 
memorandums of association, and corporate governance structures.  
 
17.  An  analysis  of  regulatory  framework  as  per  international  best  practices  will  be 
undertaken to provide guidance on regulatory reform. The proposed regulatory road maps 
would  be  guided  by  the  need  to  operationalize  new  sector  and  legislative  arrangements. 
Appropriate  training  modules  and  workshops  to  garner  support  for  proposed  will  also  be 
developed.  
 
18.  In addition to the five core activities (para. 16), the TA will provide support to the DEA in 
(i) evaluating proposed PPP processes and sector and project structures; (ii) PPP knowledge 
management through developing and implementing a communication strategy; and (iii) building 
capacity to manage the new PPP entity, policy framework, manual, and pipeline of projects for 
process approvals under the new PPP frameworks built under the TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $1,250,000 equivalent, of which ADB will finance 
$1,000,000 equivalent as a grant from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other 
sources). The Government will provide the balance of $250,000 to meet local currency costs 
and cover counterpart staff, office facilities, administrative support, facilitation for meetings, and 
other expenses. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The DEA of the Ministry of Finance will be the executing and implementing agency for 
the TA. Project performance will be periodically appraised by ADB review missions, DEA staff, 
and other stakeholders. Guidance will be sought from the DEA, market participants, and other 
stakeholders to resolve issues that may arise in implementation. A steering committee chaired 
by DEA will be established to ensure the quality of deliverables, adherence to timelines, and 
suitability  of  suggested  mechanisms  to  suit  Indian  conditions.  The  steering  committee  will 
include  line  ministries,  state  and  central  representatives,  and  representatives  of  regulatory 
bodies. 
 
21.  The TA will engage consultancy firms and individuals to undertake core activities in three 
groups: (i) PPP policy framework and PPP manual development; (ii) the development of the 
national PPP entity, 3 P India; and (iii) the development of regulatory road maps. In addition, 
consultancy support will be provided for developing and managing a communications strategy; 
undertaking reviews of proposed policies, process, and structures; and managing the new entity 
and policy frameworks during a transition period in which the DEA’s capacity will be enhanced. 
Consulting inputs are estimated at 106 person-months, both national and international, provided 
by consulting firms and individuals. The consulting firms and individuals must have a broad 
range  of  skills  in  PPP  and  financial  structuring,  regulatory  economics,  corporate  and 
constitutional  law,  institutional  development,  management  consultancy,  communications 
expertise, and project administration. Selection of the firms and individuals will be made in 
consultation with the DEA and in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance 
with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.7  The  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
22.  DEA will provide the office space and logistical and administrative support necessary to 
implement the project. Equipment and materials to be financed by the TA will be procured in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 8 TA 
implementation  will  last  24  months,  from  December  2009  to  December  2011.  ADB  will 
disseminate project results, and evaluation results will be made available on the ADB website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Assisting in Framework Development for Mainstreaming Public–
Private Partnerships, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  To deliver the technical assistance (TA) outcomes, consultancy skills will be required in 
(i)  international  and  national  corporate  law,  (ii)  national  constitutional  law  and  regulatory 
economics, (iii) institutional development, and (iv) knowledge management and training.  
 
2.  National  and  international  consultants,  both  individuals  and  firms,  will  include  (i) 
international consulting firms with expertise in the infrastructure sector with specific reference to 
public–private  partnership  (PPP),  PPP  policy  development,  business  planning,  corporate 
governance and strategic management, regulatory economics, and government infrastructure 
advise; (ii) individual expert consultants with experience in communications and marketing, 
developing training modules and workshops, and conducting road shows; and (iii) individual 
expert consultants with experience in project management, PPP program management, and 
capacity building. A nodal officer from an international law firm will be appointed to report to the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and/or the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA).  
 
3.  TA coordination will be conducted by a designated project officer in the DEA, which is 
the executing and implementing agency for the TA. The designated officer will be responsible 
for providing guidance and resolving issues that may arise during implementation. ADB will 
assist in procuring consultants and equipment, as the TA is a grant. ADB will also assist in 
coordinating across various entities and supervising TA implementation.  
 
4.  The outline terms of reference for each consultant in this document are not exhaustive 
and may be supplemented and expanded as required to meet DEA and ADB requirements. 
 
A.  Regulation  Consulting  Firm  (international,  2  person-months;  national,  6  person- 
months) 
 
5.  The  international  regulation  consulting  firm  will  provide  inputs  for  improving  the 
regulatory  framework  for  PPP.  It  will  have  over  10  years  of  international  experience  in 
infrastructure regulation, ideally in both developing and developed markets. The firm will have 
strong credentials in regulatory economics with regard to the interface between regulatory and 
commercial  interests.  The  firm  will  provide  advice  on  legal  and  regulatory  reform  while 
conducting a comparative analysis of central and state legislation in line with international best 
practices. The international firm will be responsible for  
(i)  undertaking comparative analysis of central and state legislation and regulatory 
arrangements, 
(ii)  undertaking comparative analysis of PPP regulation in India and international 
best practices, 
(iii)  undertaking comparative analysis of the government role in infrastructure across 
developing and developed markets, and 
(iv)  providing guidance on legislative and regulatory reform based on a comparative 
analysis with international best practices and in light of the evolving PPP policy 
framework. 
 
B.  Public–Private Partnership Policy Consulting Firm (international, 2 person-months; 
national, 18 person-months)  
 
6.  The  international  PPP  policy  consulting  firm  will  have  10  years  of  international 
experience in PPP policy development and PPP project-development processes in various 
markets. In addition, the firm will ideally have been involved in developing PPP manuals in other 
markets and have built up a knowledge base on all aspects of the PPP project-development

cycle,  including  financial  and  legal  assessment,  statutory  project  assessment,  project 
management,  stakeholder  consultation,  risk  assessment  and  output  specification,  payment 
mechanisms, and contractual issues, etc. The international firm will be responsible for  
(i)  analyzing existing PPP policy documents; 
(ii)  analyzing and reviewing national, state, and sector approaches on risk allocation, 
documentation, and PPP project development and bid processes, etc., which 
may involve reviewing documents and discussions with government bodies in

(iii)  assessing international approaches to risk allocation, documentation, and bid

(iv)  conducting  consultations  with  stakeholders,  including  the  private  sector,  and 
preparing documents to set out the PPP policy manual; 
(v)  developing a draft set of principles for the PPP policy; and 
(vi)  developing  a  PPP  policy  manual  for  the  legislative  and  regulatory  process 
containing  detailed  instructions  on  procedures  to  be  followed  during  project 
identification, planning, procurement, implementation, and monitoring.   
 
C.  Institutional Development Consulting Firm (international, 2 person-months; national, 
18 person-months) 
 
7.  The  international  institutional  development  consulting  firm  will  have  10  years  of 
international experience in advising on institutional development and corporate governance 
frameworks. Ideally, it will have worked in a variety of markets and developed a knowledge base 
on  institutional  development  with  reference  to  PPP-related  institutions.  Similar  work  by 
consultants fielded by the firm in other PPP knowledge-management institutions would be an 
added  advantage.  Integral  to  the  development  of  the  PPP  manual  will  be  developing  a 
knowledge bank of mandatory and optional legal clauses for optimal risk allocation. Thus, the 
responsibilities of the proposed institution are closely related to the development of the PPP 
policy and PPP manual. The international firm will be responsible for  
(i)  analyzing  existing  PPP  knowledge-management  and  contract-development 
institutions in other markets; 
(ii)  reviewing  the  need  for  a  knowledge-management  and  contract-advisory 
institution in India; 
(iii)  developing a business plan for the proposed body based on the needs of the 
sector; 
(iv)  developing a revenue model based on a market assessment of services offered 
by the proposed body; 
(v)  drafting the documentation required for setting up a knowledge-management 
body, including articles of association, memorandums of understanding, charter, 
etc.; and 
(vi)  advising on an appropriate corporate governance structure for the proposed body, 
including the degree and structure of private sector participation.

8.  National legal consulting services will be required to assist the international consulting 
firms regarding national corporate and constitutional law. The national legal consultant(s) will 
ideally have 10 years of expertise in both constitutional and national corporate law in the 
infrastructure sector in India, as well as with infrastructure regulation. The national institutional 
development  specialist  will  assist  in  developing  the  institutional  and  corporate  governance
